Description: Well-fashioned, elongated bronze axe-head: with a very narrow, roughly cylindrical waist, an inclined butt with thin angular lugs, and a deep circular cutting end. The cutting edge is sharp and bears a number of small nicks, which may be the result of wear. The blade is lightly corroded.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt) (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tools and weapons : illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London' (London, 1917), 9, pl. II, 89; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), no, G-VI/2, pl. XIII, 4; 'Les amour d'une princesse égyptienne' (Saint-Gérard, 1997), p.133 [138].
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (154)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1997 May-Oct, Abbaye Saint-Gerard De Brogne, Le Roman de la momie
